prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for shutting off the WiFi.
Our kids are good kids but don’t do enough around the house, particularly on housework day. Wifey & I are often still finishing after dark. Son (18) is also addicted to league of legends. He is 2nd year university and lives at home without paying for anything except his clothes, bus money & spending.

I (M49) got started about 8am this morning (Saturday). Didn’t feel very motivated because I’m in NZ, yesterday was the day 49 people were gunned down at their Mosques and Christchurch is my home town so I’m feeling pretty down. At about 9:30 I knocked on his door to ask if he could start on his jobs & empty the dishwasher. He was in a game & said yeah yeah.

No sign of him and an hour later my wife said she’d just asked him and he said he was in the middle of a game. She told him she’d get me to cut the wifi if he didn’t start helping and he said if she did that he wouldn’t be doing anything. (Once a game starts you can’t quit without risking a stand down for several days).

When I heard that I went straight to the router, disconnected the power cable & put it away. A minute or two later he starts yelling from downstairs. I went down there and he begins shouting and swearing at me (f***ing this & that). I told him calmly he had just lost internet until I decided to give it back & so of course he escalated the shouting. I went back upstairs feeling very bruised.

He was up within 5 mins, went to the fridge & got an apple. I told him if he was going to yell at me like that he can’t expect to eat my food and can buy his own. Even more shouting and swearing. Youngest daughter (11) tried to tell him to stop and got the brunt of it. She has OCD & Aspergers so can’t cope with that sort of thing and I sent her upstairs. Son threw the apple, kicked the washing basket over (talking a chip out of the coffee table) & stormed downstairs.

Ten minutes later I heard what sounded like a door slam over & over. When I went downstairs I saw the doorframe to his bedroom is split top to bottom. I told him he has to fix it.

Wife calmed things down & later he even washed her car. She drove him to work at 6pm by which stage we still hadn’t exchanged words. He’d already planned to stay at a friend’s so he’s probably getting plastered. It’s midnight now & wifey is worried because “he’s not in a good state of mind.” I can’t help worrying too. He’s not answering her texts.

I’m tossing up whether to (1) programme the router to exclude all his devices; and/or (2) take his bedroom door away. However at 18 he’s an adult. I don’t know whether ITA, HTA or NTA. 
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to work through this. The user is asking if the person who shut off the WiFi is in the wrong. Let's start by understanding the situation.

The father (AITA) lives in New Zealand. His son is 18, in university, and lives at home without paying except for clothes, bus money, and spending. The son is addicted to League of Legends. On a Saturday, the father is feeling down due to a recent tragedy in his hometown, Christchurch. He asks the son to do chores, but the son is in a game. The son ignores the request, and when the mother threatens to cut WiFi, the son says he won't help if they do that. The father then cuts the WiFi, leading to an argument. The son yells, swears, throws an apple, and kicks over a washing basket. The daughter with OCD and Aspergers gets involved, and the son damages the doorframe. The father tells him to fix it. Later, the son washes the car and leaves, but the parents are worried.

The user thinks the author is in the wrong, but wants to know my opinion. The options are A (yes, wrong) or B (no). 

First, the father's actions: cutting WiFi to enforce chores. Is that a fair parenting strategy? Well, the son is 18, an adult. The parents expect him to contribute. If he's not doing his part, cutting a privilege like internet might be a way to enforce responsibility. However, the son is in a game that has consequences if he leaves. The father's action might have caused the son to lose a game, which the son might see as unfair. 

But the son's response was aggressive. Yelling, swearing, damaging property. That's a problem. The father's response after that—telling him to fix the door—is appropriate. But the initial act of cutting WiFi, while maybe a parent's way to enforce chores, could be seen as overstepping since the son is an adult. However, considering the son is living at home and not contributing, the parents have a right to set boundaries. 

On the other hand, cutting WiFi abruptly without discussion might have triggered the outburst. Maybe a better approach would be to have a conversation about responsibilities, especially since the son is an adult. The father's reaction could be seen as a failure to communicate, leading to the son's anger. 

The son's behavior is definitely wrong—shouting, swearing, throwing things. But the question is about the father. The father's actions led to this escalation. He might have handled it differently. But the son's refusal to help and the threat about the WiFi might have justified the father's action. However, the father's decision to take away WiFi without considering the son's circumstances (like the game's rules) might be part of the problem. 

In terms of the father being in the wrong: cutting WiFi is a common strategy for parents with younger kids, but with an 18-year-old adult, it might be more about respecting his autonomy. The father might have overreacted by cutting the WiFi without a proper discussion. Also, the son's response was extreme, but the father's actions might have contributed to that. 

So, considering all factors, maybe the father is in the wrong for cutting the WiFi without a more mature approach, leading to the conflict. Therefore, answer A (yes).
